title: Cosmos
author: Carl Sagan
description: A journey through the universe exploring astronomy and cosmology
abstract: Cosmos traces the origins of knowledge and the scientific method, mixing science with philosophy, and speculating to the future of science. Sagan rejects an anthropocentric viewpoint of the universe, considering it in its proper cosmic context.
toc:
Chapter 1: The Shores of the Cosmic Ocean
Chapter 2: One Voice in the Cosmic Fugue
Chapter 3: The Harmony of Worlds
Chapter 4: Heaven and Hell
Chapter 5: Blues for a Red Planet
subjects: astronomy, cosmology, science, philosophy, universe, space exploration

title: A Brief History of Time
author: Stephen Hawking
description: From the Big Bang to black holes - cosmology explained
abstract: A landmark volume in science writing by one of the great minds of our time, Stephen Hawking's book explores such profound questions as: How did the universe begin—and what made its start possible?
toc:
Chapter 1: Our Picture of the Universe
Chapter 2: Space and Time
Chapter 3: The Expanding Universe
Chapter 4: The Uncertainty Principle
Chapter 5: Elementary Particles and the Forces of Nature
subjects: physics, cosmology, black holes, quantum mechanics, relativity, time, space

title: The Selfish Gene
author: Richard Dawkins
abstract: The Selfish Gene caused a wave of excitement among biologists and general readers alike when it was first published in 1976. Professor Dawkins articulates a gene's eye view of evolution.
toc:
Chapter 1: Why are people?
Chapter 2: The replicators
Chapter 3: Immortal coils
Chapter 4: The gene machine
Chapter 5: Aggression: stability and the selfish machine
subjects: evolution, biology, genetics, natural selection, behavioral ecology

title: Code Complete
author: Steve McConnell
description: A practical handbook of software construction
abstract: Widely considered one of the best practical guides to programming, Steve McConnell's original CODE COMPLETE has been helping developers write better software for more than a decade.
toc:
Part I: Laying the Foundation
Chapter 1: Welcome to Software Construction
Chapter 2: Metaphors for a Richer Understanding of Software Development
Part II: Creating High-Quality Code
Chapter 3: Measure Twice, Cut Once: Upstream Prerequisites
subjects: software engineering, programming, code quality, software construction, best practices

title: Introduction to Algorithms
author: Thomas H. Cormen
description: Comprehensive textbook on algorithms and data structures
abstract: Some books on algorithms are rigorous but incomplete; others cover masses of material but lack rigor. Introduction to Algorithms uniquely combines rigor and comprehensiveness.
toc:
Part I: Foundations
Chapter 1: The Role of Algorithms in Computing
Chapter 2: Getting Started
Part II: Sorting and Order Statistics
Chapter 6: Heapsort
Chapter 7: Quicksort
subjects: algorithms, data structures, computer science, programming, complexity analysis

title: Zero to One
author: Peter Thiel
description: Notes on startups and building the future
abstract: The great secret of our time is that there are still uncharted frontiers to explore and new inventions to create. In Zero to One, legendary entrepreneur and investor Peter Thiel shows how we can find singular ways to create those new things.
toc:
Chapter 1: The Challenge of the Future
Chapter 2: Party Like It's 1999
Chapter 3: All Happy Companies Are Different
Chapter 4: The Ideology of Competition
Chapter 5: Last Mover Advantage
subjects: entrepreneurship, startups, innovation, business strategy, technology, venture capital

title: Structures: Or Why Things Don't Fall Down
author: J.E. Gordon
description: The science of structural engineering explained
abstract: In a book that will appeal to engineers and general readers alike, J.E. Gordon strips engineering of its confusing technical terms, communicating its founding principles in accessible, witty prose.
toc:
Chapter 1: Why structures carry loads
Chapter 2: The invention of stress and strain
Chapter 3: The invention of the factor of safety
Chapter 4: Stress concentrations
Chapter 5: Strain energy and modern fracture mechanics
subjects: structural engineering, mechanics, materials science, physics, construction

title: The Design of Everyday Things
author: Don Norman
description: The psychology of good design and usability
abstract: Even the smartest among us can feel inept as we fail to figure out which light switch or oven burner to turn on, or whether to push, pull, or slide a door. The fault lies not in ourselves, but in product design.
toc:
Chapter 1: The Psychopathology of Everyday Things
Chapter 2: The Psychology of Everyday Actions
Chapter 3: Knowledge in the Head and in the World
Chapter 4: Knowing What to Do
Chapter 5: Human Error? No, Bad Design
subjects: design, usability, human-computer interaction, psychology, user experience, product design

title: Calculus: Early Transcendentals
author: James Stewart
abstract: Stewart's CALCULUS: EARLY TRANSCENDENTALS has the mathematical precision, accuracy, clarity of exposition and outstanding examples and problem sets that have made it the most widely used calculus textbook.
toc:
Chapter 1: Functions and Models
Chapter 2: Limits and Derivatives
Chapter 3: Differentiation Rules
Chapter 4: Applications of Differentiation
Chapter 5: Integrals
Chapter 6: Applications of Integration
subjects: calculus, mathematics, derivatives, integrals, limits, mathematical analysis

title: Linear Algebra Done Right
author: Sheldon Axler
description: A modern approach to linear algebra
abstract: This text for a second course in linear algebra, aimed at math majors and graduate students, adopts a novel approach by banishing determinants to the end of the book and focusing on understanding the structure of linear operators on vector spaces.
toc:
Chapter 1: Vector Spaces
Chapter 2: Finite-Dimensional Vector Spaces
Chapter 3: Linear Maps
Chapter 4: Polynomials
Chapter 5: Eigenvalues, Eigenvectors, and Invariant Subspaces
subjects: linear algebra, vector spaces, matrices, eigenvalues, mathematical theory

title: Sapiens: A Brief History of Humankind
author: Yuval Noah Harari
description: The story of how humans conquered the world
abstract: From a renowned historian comes a groundbreaking narrative of humanity's creation and evolution—a #1 international bestseller—that explores the ways in which biology and history have defined us and enhanced our understanding of what it means to be 'human.'
toc:
Part One: The Cognitive Revolution
Chapter 1: An Animal of No Significance
Chapter 2: The Tree of Knowledge
Part Two: The Agricultural Revolution
Chapter 5: History's Biggest Fraud
Part Three: The Unification of Humankind
subjects: anthropology, human evolution, civilization, cognitive revolution, agricultural revolution, history

title: Guns, Germs, and Steel
author: Jared Diamond
description: The fates of human societies explained
abstract: In this groundbreaking work, evolutionary biologist Jared Diamond stunningly dismantles racially based theories of human history by revealing the environmental factors actually responsible for history's broadest patterns.
toc:
Prologue: Yali's Question
Part One: From Eden to Cajamarca
Chapter 1: Up to the Starting Line
Part Two: The Rise and Spread of Food Production
Chapter 4: Farmer Power
Part Three: From Food to Guns, Germs, and Steel
subjects: world history, geography, environmental determinism, civilization, agriculture, technology

title: Pride and Prejudice
author: Jane Austen
description: Classic romance novel of manners and marriage
abstract: When Elizabeth Bennet meets Fitzwilliam Darcy, she believes he is the last man on earth she could ever marry. But as their lives become intertwined in unexpected ways, she finds herself captivated by the very person she swore to loathe.
toc:
Chapter 1: It is a truth universally acknowledged...
Chapter 2: Mr. Bennet was among the earliest of those who waited on Mr. Bingley
Chapter 3: Not all that Mrs. Bennet, however, with the assistance of her five daughters
Chapter 4: When Jane and Elizabeth were alone
subjects: romance, social commentary, marriage, class, 19th century literature, British literature

title: The Lord of the Rings
author: J.R.R. Tolkien
abstract: In ancient times the Rings of Power were crafted by the Elven-smiths, and Sauron, the Dark Lord, forged the One Ring, filling it with his own power so that he could rule all others. But the One Ring was taken from him, and though he sought it throughout Middle-earth, it remained lost to him.
toc:
Book I: The Ring Sets Out
Chapter 1: A Long-expected Party
Chapter 2: The Shadow of the Past
Book II: The Ring Goes South
Chapter 1: Many Meetings
Book III: The Treason of Isengard
subjects: fantasy, adventure, mythology, good vs evil, heroism, friendship, epic literature

author: George Orwell
abstract: Among the seminal texts of the 20th century, Nineteen Eighty-Four is a rare work that grows more haunting as its futuristic purgatory becomes more real. Published in 1949, the book offers political satirist George Orwell's nightmare vision of a totalitarian, bureaucratic world.
toc:
Part One
Chapter 1: It was a bright cold day in April, and the clocks were striking thirteen
Chapter 2: As he put his hand to the door-knob Winston saw that he had left the diary open
Part Two
Chapter 1: It was the middle of the morning, and Winston had left the cubicle to go to the lavatory
subjects: dystopia, totalitarianism, surveillance, political fiction, social criticism, thought control

title: Advaced English Grammar
author: Martin Hewings
description: A self study reference and practice book for advanvced south asian students
